newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Frozen Russian MinFins revised down to $129,000.
newsitem.headline: Frozen Russian MinFins revised down to $129,000.

text.p: The amount of MinFin bonds frozen this month by police total $129,000, not $180,000 as announced earlier, a senior official from Vneshtorgbank, the main MinFin depositary, said on Thursday.

According to a detailed breakdown of frozen bonds, issued by Andrei Remnyov, deputy head of the bank's depositary, police from one precinct had frozen bonds worth $39,000 on May 7, and police from a second had seized bonds worth $90,000 on May 13.
Earlier on Thursday Remnyov had estimated the amount frozen by the second police group at nearly $140,000, not $90,000.

The total amount frozen is a tiny fraction of the total $11 billion nominal value of MinFin bonds outstanding, but rumours of the moves hit prices in trading on Thursday before the Vneshtorgbank statement allowed them to recover.
Remnyov said Vneshekonombank, the payment agent for the bonds, had stopped handling them on May 14 because of the police action.

There was no explanation why the bonds had been frozen. Last year the authorities froze about $74 million of the bearer bonds, which were subsequently released, because they had been stolen or misused.
Remnyov issued the following bond details:
Series number Denomination Tranche Number Date frozen
